it.unitn.ing.rista.awt
Class DownFlowLayout

java.lang.Object
  it.unitn.ing.rista.awt.DownFlowLayout
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.LayoutManager, java.io.Serializable
public class DownFlowLayout
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.awt.LayoutManager, java.io.Serializable

A down flow layout arranges components in a up-to-down flow, much like lines of text in a paragraph. Down flow layouts are typically used to arrange buttons in a panel. It will arrange buttons up to down until no more buttons fit on the same column. Each component is centered.

A down flow layout lets each component assume its natural (preferred) size.

Since:
JDK1.1
See Also:

Constructor Detail

DownFlowLayout

public DownFlowLayout()
Constructs a new Down Flow Layout with a centered alignment and a default 5-unit horizontal and vertical gap.

Since:
JDK1.1

DownFlowLayout

public DownFlowLayout(int align)
Constructs a new Down Flow Layout with the specified alignment and a default 5-unit horizontal and vertical gap. The value of the alignment argument must be one of DownFlowLayout.TOP, DownFlowLayout.BOTTOM, or DownFlowLayout.CENTER.

Parameters:
align - the alignment value
Since:
JDK1.1

DownFlowLayout

public DownFlowLayout(int align,
                      int hgap,
                      int vgap)
Creates a new down flow layout manager with the indicated alignment and the indicated horizontal and vertical gaps.

The value of the alignment argument must be one of DownFlowLayout.TOP, DownFlowLayout.BOTTOM, or DownFlowLayout.CENTER.

Parameters:
align - the alignment value.
hgap - the horizontal gap between components.
vgap - the vertical gap between components.
Since:
JDK1.1

layoutContainer

public void layoutContainer(java.awt.Container target)
Lays out the container. This method lets each component take its preferred size by reshaping the components in the target container in order to satisfy the constraints of this DownFlowLayout object.

Specified by:
layoutContainer in interface java.awt.LayoutManager
Parameters:
target - the specified component being laid out.
Since:
JDK1.0
